articles.headline: In Recession, China Solidifies Its Lead in Global Trade
articles.snippet: Aided by demand for low-cost goods in the recession and a government that staunchly supports exports, China’s grip on world trade has strengthened.
articles.abstract: Aided by demand for low-cost goods in the recession and a government that staunchly supports exports, China’s grip on world trade has strengthened.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  With the global recession making consumers and businesses more price-conscious, China is grabbing market share from its export competitors, solidifying a dominance in world trade that many economists say could last long after any economic recovery.

articles.headline: U.S. Pay Czar Tries Again to Trim A.I.G. Bonuses
articles.snippet: The federal pay czar is trying to persuade the insurance giant A.I.G. to reduce a coming payment worth $198 million but is running into legal hurdles.
articles.abstract: The federal pay czar is trying to persuade the insurance giant A.I.G. to reduce a coming payment worth $198 million but is running into legal hurdles.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal pay czar is trying to force the American International Group to reduce $198 million in bonuses promised to employees of its trading unit, where problems posed a threat to the global financial system last year.

articles.headline: Still on the Job, but at Half the Pay
articles.snippet: Pay cuts are occurring more frequently than at any time since the Great Depression.
articles.abstract: Pay cuts are occurring more frequently than at any time since the Great Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: MECHANICSVILLE, Va.  The dark blue captain’s hat, with its golden oak-leaf clusters, sits atop a bookcase in Bryan Lawlor’s home, out of reach of the children. The uniform their father wears still displays the four stripes of a commercial airline captain, but the hat stays home. The rules forbid that extra display of authority, now that Mr. Lawlor has been downgraded to first officer.

articles.headline: Saudis Seek Payments for Any Drop in Oil Revenues
articles.snippet: Saudi officials reiterated a call for oil-producing countries to be compensated if rich nations reduce their consumption, in advance of negotiations in December.
articles.abstract: Saudi officials reiterated a call for oil-producing countries to be compensated if rich nations reduce their consumption, in advance of negotiations in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia is trying to enlist other oil-producing countries to support a provocative idea: if wealthy countries reduce their oil consumption to combat global warming, they should pay compensation to oil producers.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Andrew C. Revkin

articles.headline: Hybrid Cars May Include Fake Vroom for Safety
articles.snippet: Makers of hybrid and electric vehicles are working to let them emit sounds, so people can hear them approaching.
articles.abstract: Makers of hybrid and electric vehicles are working to let them emit sounds, so people can hear them approaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, automakers have been on a quest to make cars quieter: an auto that purrs, and glides almost silently in traffic.

articles.headline: Biden No Longer a Lone Voice on Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pessimism on Afghanistan has caught on with many liberal Democrats.
articles.abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pessimism on Afghanistan has caught on with many liberal Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A few hours after getting off a plane from America’s war zones, Joseph R. Biden Jr. slipped into a chair, shook off his jet lag and reflected on what he had seen. The situation in Iraq, he said, was much improved. In Pakistan, he said he saw encouraging signs.

articles.headline: E-Mail Shows Concerns Over Merrill Deal
articles.snippet: E-mail messages were handed over to government investigators as Bank of America opened a collection of documents that it had kept secret about the ill-fated merger with Merrill Lynch.
articles.abstract: E-mail messages were handed over to government investigators as Bank of America opened a collection of documents that it had kept secret about the ill-fated merger with Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was Jan. 15, and the government was about to hand Bank of America its second taxpayer lifeline as the bank was drowning in losses from its recent marriage to Merrill Lynch.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Still Hoping to Sell Music by the Month
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs with various approaches say they believe they can finally make online music subscriptions work.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs with various approaches say they believe they can finally make online music subscriptions work.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The idea of selling monthly subscriptions to a vast catalog of online music has met with only limited success. That isn’t stopping a new batch of entrepreneurs from trying to make it work.
